5.13pm BST

Closing summary

Time for a recap:

  • Sainsburyâ€™s is on track to become Britainâ€™s biggest supermarket after agreeing a deal with Asdaâ€™s owner, Walmart. Under the deal, Walmart will own 42% of the combined company, which will control around a third of supermarket revenues.

  • The two companies have agreed that prices could fall by up to 10% on some popular items if the deal is approved.

    They have also pledged not to close stores or lay off store staff - however, analysts believe some stores will be sold off to rivals.

My colleague Sarah Butler explains:

The merger of the UKâ€™s second and third largest retailers is expected to trigger a major inquiry which analysts predict will result in at least 75 stores having to be disposed of. It would be the biggest shake-up in the market since the merger of Morrison and Safeway in 2003 when dozens of stores changed hands.

Sainsburyâ€™s takeover of Asda is not expected to complete until the second half of next year as regulators crunch the numbers on potential overlap between the two groupsâ€™ stores.

Mike Coupe, the Sainsburyâ€™s chief executive who plans to lead the merged business, said the deal was a â€œtransformational opportunity to create a new force in UK retail, which will be more competitive and give customers more of what they want now and in the futureâ€�.

  • Shares in Sainsburyâ€™s have surged 15% today, closing at their highest level since the summer of 2014.

  • MPs have warned that the deal could cost jobs, hurt competition, and lead to store closures - despite Sainsbury and Asdaâ€™s promises.
  • Labour are calling for an full, urgent probe into the deal.
    Government minister Andrew Griffiths, though, has argued that the retail sector is going through tough times - and that Sainsbury and Asda are trying to get ahead of the curve.
  • In banking, TSB customers are still struggling to access their accounts after more than a week of disruption. Lloyds Bank has also suffered from IT gremlins today, with some users unable to get its app to work.
  • The Treasury Committee has announced that it will question TSBâ€™s chief, Paul Pester, on Wednesday.

Thatâ€™s all for today. Thanks for reading and commenting. GW

4.52pm BST

Back in the City, shares in Sainsbury have closed 15% higher, as traders welcome its proposed takeover of Asda.

That adds some Â£858m to Sainsburyâ€™s market capitalisation, pushing it up to Â£6.78bn.

4.47pm BST

Asked again about the future of stores, minister Andrew Griffiths repeats that Sainsbury and Asda are pledging that no stores will close, and no jobs within stores will be lost.

But Labour MP Justin Madders isnâ€™t convinced - he says workers will pay the price of the Â£500m of efficiency savings planned under the deal.

Q: Attacks on terms and conditions are inevitable; what will the minister do in two years when that has happened?

Griffiths replies that his powers were laid out in the Enterprise Act 2002 -- the decision on whether to allow the deal now rests with the CMA.

And thatâ€™s the end of the urgent question.

4.42pm BST

Dromey: Government is 'waxing lyrical' about Sainsbury-Asda deal

Jack Dromey MP, a former top official at the Unite union, tells the House that supermarkets are powerful, as employers and across their supply chains.

They must not be allowed to abuse that power, Dromey tells fellow MPs. Does the minister understand the â€œdismayâ€� among employees about this deal, which came â€œout of the blueâ€� at the weekend.

Dromey accuses Griffiths of â€˜waxing lyricalâ€™ about Sainsbury and Asdaâ€™s promises (for example...); will he act to ensure that these are not just Day One guarantees, but can be counted on in years to come?

Griffiths replies that it is â€˜early daysâ€™, and points out that the current government brought in the Groceries Code Adjudicator to protect farmers and other suppliers.

4.35pm BST

Q: How long will workers and customers face uncertainty over this deal, and what impact will this have on portfolio investment?

Andrew Griffiths says that Sainsbury and Asda hope the CMA will hold a â€˜fast-trackâ€™ review. If that happens, then the detailed Phase 2 investigation could be completed in six months.

4.32pm BST

Labour MP Susan Elan Jones asks a straight question -- does the minister think this is a good deal or a bad deal for British farming?

But she doesnâ€™t get a straight answer.

Minister Andrew Griffiths says the deal must be considered by the shareholders of Asda and Sainsburyâ€™s â€“ so itâ€™s not appropriate for the government to pass judgement.

4.30pm BST

Labourâ€™s Chris Matheson is also worried that jobs will be lost among the distribution chain that serve Sainsbury and Asda stores today.

Matheson points out that many distribution centres were sighted to replace lost manufacturing jobs; what guarantees can the government give to those â€œdifficult areasâ€�?

Andrew Griffiths says his constituency, Burton, contains some distribution jobs (itâ€™s in the middle of the country).

However, he makes two points:

  • First of all... the number of supermarkets served will be the same if the deal goes through, so the number of lorries and goods will be the same
  • Second, the issue of job losses is not one that the government can consider under the Enterprise Act.

4.23pm BST

Philip Hollobone, Conservative MP for Kettering, says his constituency currently has a large Sainsburyâ€™s and a large Asda.

Workers and shoppers want to know - will we still have both stores in two years time?

In reply, minister Andrew Griffiths says that Kettering shoppers and workers want to know they have choice and competition, and that those jobs are protected.

If they are both â€œthriving supermarketsâ€�, either the CMA will decide there isnâ€™t a competition issue and allow the combined company to keep running both, or it will say there are competition issues, and one will be sold, Griffiths explains.

4.17pm BST

Conservative MP Stephen Kerr says the concentration of supermarket power could have a â€œpotentially devastating effectâ€� on suppliers. Will their voices be heard?

Griffiths replies that suppliers will be included in the CMAâ€™s investigation.

4.16pm BST

4.15pm BST

The CMA will consider what happens in constituencies where there currently Sainsbury and Asda stores close together, Andrew Griffiths says.

If they believe it will be anti-competitive for both supermarkets to be there, they will force a sale to a competitor.

4.09pm BST

Conservative MP: Asda's HQ will close

Conservative MP Mark Menzies says he worked in Asdaâ€™s head office for 11 years.

He doesnâ€™t believe â€œthat placeâ€� will be there in a few years, so thereâ€™s no point the government trying to make promises about jobs.

Menzies also criticises the government for calling the deal a merger - itâ€™s a takeover by Sainsburyâ€™s, he insists, so â€œlets stop using false terminologyâ€�.

Finally, Menzies urges the government to protect workers in distribution centres across the country; otherwise, they will be â€œabsolutely hammeredâ€� if this deal goes ahead.

In response, Andrew Griffiths says it is a merger legally.

There will be efficiency savings, he says, but Sainsbury and Asda have assured the government that they will continue to operate as different businesses.

4.03pm BST

Labourâ€™s Rachel Reeves says workers at Asdaâ€™s headquarters in Leeds (in her constituency) will be â€˜incredibly concerned about their futureâ€™ given the lack of assurances about jobs.

Q: The industrial strategy is about rebalancing the economy away from London - what assurances can the government give that this deal wonâ€™t rebalance jobs away from Yorkshire?

Business minister Andrew Griffiths points out that many high street names have been lost in recent years, due to the changing retail climate [ie, competition from Amazon]

Todayâ€™s deal shows â€œtwo businesses trying to get ahead of the curve and future-proof themselves in a vey challenging marketâ€� he adds.

Thatâ€™s quite an endorsement from the government bench - Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda must be delighted.

3.56pm BST

3.54pm BST

Labour MP Hilary Benn asks whether jobs are at risk at Sainsburyâ€™s headquarters.

Minister Andrew Griffiths says he doesnâ€™t yet have any reassurances, beyond the promise that both companyâ€™s HQs will be kept open.

Conservative MP Robert Halfon suggests that Sainsburyâ€™s could break its commitment not to eliminate store workers, once the merger has gone through.

Griffiths encourages Halfon to engage with the CMA and both companies over his concerns.

3.50pm BST

Conservative MP Andrew Selous says his Dunstable constituency has an Asda and a Sainsburyâ€™s close to each other, with a clutch of other supermarket outlets - and an Amazon fulfillment centre - close by. What might the Competition and Markets Authority think about this situation?

The honourable member is spoiled for choice, minister Andrew Griffiths replies.

3.47pm BST

Sainsbury-Asda deal discussed in parliament

Over in parliament, the government is facing an urgent question on the Sainsbury-Asda deal.

Labourâ€™s Rebecca Long Bailey is putting the question now, asking whether the deal will lead to job cuts.

She also warns that the merger will â€œradically alter the whole grocery sectorâ€�, affecting suppliers and farmers as well as customers and staff.

The government urgently needs to needs to broaden out the public interest test applied to takeover teals, Long Bailey says, to protect these people.

Business minister Andrew Griffiths responds, saying he has spoken to the CEOs of Sainsbury and Asda this morning, and told them that it was important to treat suppliers fairly.

Griffiths tells the House that he told the companies the important of engaging with the unions..... and that he had received assurances that both head offices will remain open.

But... Griffiths also points out that the retail sector is in a period of huge flux - the way people are shopping is changing fast, so retailers must change and adapt.

Griffiths also cited Sainsburyâ€™s claim that prices will be cut, by up to 10% for popular items.

3.35pm BST

Retail analyst Mark Brumby has a few thoughts on the Sainsbury-Asda deal:

3.20pm BST

Haldane: Economists can learn from World of Warcraft

You can usually rely on the Bank of Englandâ€™s chief economist for an eye-catching speech with a few choice quotes.

And today, Andy Haldane has argued that music streaming site Spotify and online game World Of Warcraft can teach economists a few lessons on how to handle data.

To be honest, Haldane actually made these comments more than a week ago, to Kingâ€™s College Business School. But the Bank of England has only just released the text, so theyâ€™re worth looking at now.

Haldaneâ€™s theme is â€œBig Dataâ€�, and the way that central bankers can use the explosion of data in recent years to get a better picture of the economyâ€™s moving parts.

He says that a major breakthrough is close:

In time, it is possible these sorts of data could help to create a real-time map of financial and activity flows across the economy, in much the same way as is already done for flows of traffic or information or weather.

Once mapped, there would then be scope to model and, through policy, modify these flows. This is an idea I first talked about six years ago. Today, it looks closer than ever to being within our grasp.

Haldane argued that behavioural economists could explore â€œnon-traditional meansâ€� when trying to forecast how people will behave....

To give one recent example, data on music downloads from Spotify has been used, in tandem with semantic search techniques applied to the words of songs, to provide an indicator of peopleâ€™s sentiment. Intriguingly, the resulting index of sentiment does at least as well in tracking consumer spending as the Michigan survey of consumer confidence.

And why stop at music? Peopleâ€™s tastes in books, TV and radio may also offer a window on their soul. So too might their taste in games. Indeed, I am interested in the potential for using gaming techniques, not just to extract data on peopleâ€™s preferences, but as a means of generating data on preferences and actions.

Haldane also suggests that todayâ€™s massive multiplayer online games could work as a sandbox for economists to examine behaviour -- to aid forecasting the next time thereâ€™s a crisis.

A gaming environment could be used to understand behaviour in a way which placed fewer restrictions. Peopleâ€™s behaviour would be observed directly in the act of game-playing which, provided this behaviour was a reasonable reflection of true behaviour, would give us new data. Because this is a virtual rather than real world, with shocks controlled and regulated, that could make it easier to address issues of causality and identification in response to shocks, including policy shocks.

There are already multi-person games with primitive economies attached to them, which allow goods and monies to change hands between participants. These include EVE Online and World of Warcraft.

The speech is online here.

2.38pm BST

The Press Association have published a Q&A on the Sainsbury-Asda deal.

Q: What will it mean for shop prices?

The two supermarket giants have pledged to invest the cost efficiencies generated from the merger into lower prices.

Sainsburyâ€™s expects to save Â£500m from merging with Asda, and has said it will lower shop prices by 10% on everyday products.

However, this could have more widespread implications for shop prices if discounters Aldi and Lidl decide to cut their prices even further to stay ahead of their main-market rivals.

Laith Khalaf, senior analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown, said: â€œThe executives of other supermarkets will have their heads in their hands at the prospect of another price war.â€�

Q: What will it mean for stores?

The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) will soon start its investigation of the proposed merger, raising the prospect that Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda will be forced to sell off stores if they directly compete in local areas.

However, Sainsburyâ€™s insisted on Monday that it does not expect to shut any stores. The supermarket says its store footprint is more focused on the south, and Asda has more stores in the north.

Q: What will happen to Argos?

Sainsburyâ€™s bought Argos in 2016 and already has more than 200 Argos outlets within its supermarkets, having rapidly expanded over the past year.

It is expected that Argos will now start appearing in Asdaâ€™s stores, with Sainsburyâ€™s chief executive Mike Coupe saying this morning that the deal â€œbrings scale in clothing and general merchandiseâ€�.

Q: Why are the two companies joining forces now?

All retailers are having to take drastic action to stay competitive during a critical time for the sector. With Amazon eyeing up the UK food market with its Amazon Fresh delivery service, food retailers will be nervous about its sprawling logistics network and buying power.

Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda also have to fend off price competition from Aldi and Lidl. As a value supermarket, Asda has been under significant pressure as the German discounters have grown their market share.

Tescoâ€™s recent merger with wholesaler Booker Group, which was cleared with minimal fuss by the CMA, will also have given executives at Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda confidence about the possibility of joining forces.

Updated at 2.42pm BST

2.11pm BST

TSB chief Paul Pester has warmed up for his looming parliamentary grilling by updating MPs about the bankâ€™s IT crisis.

Heâ€™s written to Nicky Morgan MP, answering her questions about the technology failings.

Pester says the TSB have launched a â€œproactive customer redress programmeâ€�, to meet his pledge that no customers are left out of pocket.

He also claims that TSB has made significant progress in bring its internet banking and mobile app back into use, saying

On Monday 23rd April we were only able to serve c.200,000 sessions via our website versus an expected level of c.450,000. As of Thursday 26th April, we were able to serve c.450,000. This is consistent with the number of sessions we would expect to serve.

On Monday 23rd April approximately 72% of customers attempting to access the mobile app were successful on first attempt. As of Friday 27th April this had risen to approximately 93%. This is typical of the proportion we would have seen pre-migration.

Pester also confirms that more than 400 customers saw another customerâ€™s account details - because the two accounts were linked:

TSB, like many other banks, enable customers to nominate a third party to have access to their accounts - these are called nominee accounts. Typically this will be a parent having access to a childâ€™s account or a grown-up child managing an ageing parentâ€™s account. The ability for the third party to see the customerâ€™s account information is usually limited to branch and telephony channels.

However, on the evening of Sunday 22nd April access was provided via digital channels. In addition, as well as enabling the third party to see the customerâ€™s data, the customer was able to see the third partyâ€™s data. Therefore, in the â€œparent and childâ€� example, the parent could see the childâ€™s transaction data but the child could also see the parentâ€™s transaction data.

This explains some of the comments in social media where customers expecting to be overdrawn (the â€œchildâ€�) could see large credit balances (the â€œparentâ€�). No personal data was visible, just account balance data.

Finally, Pester also admits that customers faced an average wait of one hour if they tried to phone TSB a week ago; by Thursday, this had dropped to 30 minutes (although some customers have reported much longer waits).

The full letter is online here.

1.50pm BST

TSB to face MPs over IT crisis on Wednesday

Get the popcorn in!

Britainâ€™s Treasury Committee will be grilling Paul Pester, TSBâ€™s chief executive, and the bankâ€™s chairman Richard Meddings, on Wednesday.

The committee will demand answers about exactly how TSBâ€™s IT systems collapsed more than a week ago, and how they will compensate affected customers.

Committee chair Nicky Morgan MP says:

â€œThe Treasury Committee is extremely concerned by the problems at TSB, and by the apparent miscommunication to customers about the extent and nature of these problems.

â€œItâ€™s been reported that services such as online banking have been down for some TSB customers for over a week. Many individuals and businesses will have made arrangements for the planned outage, but not for the additional time that the systems have been unavailable.

â€œWe will take evidence from TSB and Sabadell representatives to find out how they got into this mess, who is responsible, and how they are putting it right.â€�

1.07pm BST

Labour: We need an urgent investigation into Sainsbury-Asda deal

Just in: The Labour Party are calling for an urgent investigation into the Sainsbury-Asda merger.

Rebecca Long Bailey MP, Labourâ€™s Shadow Business Secretary, says the deal has â€œsignificant competition risksâ€�, and the Competition and Markets Authorities must take a proper look (ie, a phase 2 investigation)

Long Bailey says the CMA must secure â€œconcrete assurances.â€� to protect workers and suppliers.

â€œThere are risks to jobs by potential reorganisation and store closures and risks to the wider grocery industry as a Tesco/Sainsburyâ€™s-Asda duopoly emerges with unrivalled power to dominate, dictating choice and prices for consumers which in time may prove detrimental.

â€œThis unrivalled power also poses immense risk to suppliers with unprecedented bargaining power to drive suppliers prices and payment terms down which could cause instability and damage to the food and grocery manufacturing industry.

12.48pm BST

TSB IT crisis continues.... and now Lloyds users report problems

The IT crisis at TSB Bank has dragged into its second week.

Some customers are still unable to get into their accounts, 10 days after TSB tried to migrate to a new technology platform.

Experts from IBM have been working at TSB since last Thursday, to try to get its Internet banking and mobile app online. But clearly the â€˜meltdownâ€™ isnâ€™t over, given these tweets from UK businesses and retail customers:

Alarmingly, TSB isnâ€™t the only bank facing complaints today.

Lloyds Bank (which spun out TSB in 2013) has suffered â€˜intermittentâ€™ problems this morning. Its Halifax division is also caught up in the outage, as these tweets show:

11.57am BST

Sainsbury deal drives FTSE 100 to three-month high

News of Sainsburyâ€™s tie-up with Asda has driven Britainâ€™s stock market to its highest level since the start of February.

The FTSE 100 has gained 37 points, or 0.5%, to 7539 this morning.

Sainsburyâ€™s is leading the way, up 17% at a four-year high right now. Advertising giant WPP is close behind, gaining 8% after reporting better-than-expected results this morning, and saying it could sell some assets.

David Madden of CMC Markets says:

Sainsburyâ€™s shares are up 15% after the company announced plans to merge with Asda. The move is subject to regulatory approval, but should it go ahead it would be worth Â£7.3 billion. Increased competition from Aldi and Lidl is main motivation behind the proposed deal. The deep-discounters have disrupted the UK supermarket sector severely, and now have a combined market share of approximately 12%. Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda are the second and third-largest supermarkets by market share, and should the deal go ahead, it would put them in first place. Sainsburyâ€™s predict it will save Â£500 million through synergies. The retailer also updated the market with its full-year figures, as underlying pre-tax profits rose by 1.4% to Â£589 million, which was comfortably ahead of the Â£559 million expected.

WPP shares are in demand this morning after it released better-than-expected sales figures, while the advertising giant also stated a strategic review was underway. First-quarter net sales dropped by 0.1%, while analysts had expected a decline of 1%. The company also said it would take a â€˜fresh lookâ€™ at business in light of Sir Martin Sorrell stepping down earlier this month. There is talk WPP could spin off assets, but nothing has been confirmed, and no timeline has been stated.

Updated at 12.01pm BST

11.39am BST

10.58am BST

Sainsbury-Asda: What the analysts say

Simran Jagdev, companies analyst at the Economist Intelligence Unit, says Sainsburyâ€™s decision to tie-up with Asda is a surprise, partly prompted by the threat of Amazon:

The deal points to the highly competitive UK grocery market, which has long been concentrated in the hands of the top four playersâ€” Tesco, Sainsbury, Asda, Morrisons - but is now facing an onslaught from new challengers. Sainsburyâ€™s seems to be continuing the offensive against online players such as Amazon and discount grocery retailers such as Aldi and Lidl that Tesco started last year with its merger with Booker.

The deal will help Sainsbury fend off this new competition. It will also mark Walmartâ€™s operational exit from the UK, as part of its strategic decisions to instead work through partnerships in international markets.

Amisha Chohan, equity research analyst at Quilter Cheviot, says the deal is a â€œmasterstrokeâ€� - as long as the CMA approve it.

It would result in the company becoming the biggest grocer in the UK, ahead of Tesco. Its guided net synergies of over Â£500m seem prudent and we believe it could be significantly in excess of this. Sainsburyâ€™s experience from the Argos acquisition should enable it to deliver ahead of the synergy guidance.

Although this news is not ideal for Tesco, we remain positive on the UKâ€™s current largest retailer due its recent takeover of Booker, and the wholesale opportunities this will bring.â€�

Paul Mumford of Cavendish Asset Management believes Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda will be forced to sell some stores to get this deal â€œthrough the hoopâ€�:

Store disposals could naturally be offered to others in the sector with M+S and Morrisons being the most likely tenants, but itâ€™s hardly the best climate to be a net seller of large retail space. There will of course be some management synergies too, so a proclamation of no job cuts will no doubt be reversed soon enough.

This will obviously create a mighty force. But the big questions now are what influence will Walmart have on the group? And where does this leave other players? Sainsburys already has a big challenge to show that the Argos acquisition is bearing fruit, and now itâ€™s faced with driving cost synergies from Asda. The indicated 10% lower prices on regularly bought products will have raised eyebrows amongst the food producers who will fear another squeeze on margins.

10.26am BST

Competition authorities: We'll take a look

Britainâ€™s competition watchdog have confirmed they are likely to review the Sainsbury-Asda deal.

In a statement, the Competition and Markets Authority says:

This merger is likely to be subject to review by the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA).

The CMA adds that it will assess whether the merger is bad for customers.

During a Phase 1 review, the CMA would assess whether the deal could reduce competition and choice for shoppers.

After this first phase, the merger could be cleared or, if a potential reduction in competition is identified, it would be referred for an in-depth, Phase 2 investigation lasting up to 24 weeks - unless the merging parties offered immediate proposals to address any competition concerns identified.

10.17am BST

The surge in Sainsburyâ€™s shares this morning is a blow to speculators who have been betting against the supermarket.

Some major hedge funds have been â€˜shortingâ€™ Sainsburyâ€™s shares recently, by selling borrowed shares and hoping to buy them back cheaper in future. That bet seems to be unravelling, as Sainsburyâ€™s shares hit their highest level in almost four years.

As The Times explained this morning:

A little over a tenth of Sainsburyâ€™s shares were being shorted going into the weekend, with investors betting on a drop in the supermarketâ€™s share price.

Large London-based hedge funds such as Odey Asset Management, GLG and Marshall Wace have short positions in Sainsburyâ€™s amid investor anxiety about the future facing traditional retailers.

10.04am BST

Andy Brian, head of retail at Gordons law firm, also believes store closure are inevitable if this deal isnâ€™t blocked by the competition authorities:

â€œOne thing is clear; despite what is being said officially, stores would have to close. Thatâ€™s not necessarily a bad thing for the brands, although it would of course be a bad thing for those store employees.

Moving forwards, one theory is that this deal could allow Sainsburyâ€™s the freedom to compete hard against M&S Food and Waitrose at the top end of the grocery market and leave Asda to compete further on price against the other mid-market players, as well as Aldi and Lidl.

9.54am BST

Research group Edison have estimated that around 70 Asda stores could be vulnerable to sale or closure, as theyâ€™re rather close to a Sainsburyâ€™s outlet.

9.51am BST

The Federation of Small Businesses is concerned that small suppliers will be treated roughly if Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda are allowed to form a new retail titan.

FSB chairman Mike Cherry says regulators must demand firm commitments before green-lighting the deal, as Sainsbury is already talking about Â£500m of cost savings and a boost to earnings.

â€œA merger of this size will concentrate a lot of power in the hands of one giant company, and itâ€™s important that power isnâ€™t misused to coerce small suppliers into accepting unfair contracts and poor payment terms.

â€œThose at the top of Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda should explain how they plan to merge these two supply chains fairly, and give reassurance that cost savings wonâ€™t be achieved simply by milking their small suppliers for all theyâ€™re worth.

â€œWhen investigating this proposed merger, the Competition and Markets Authority should be looking for cast-iron commitments that a positive standard will be set for working with smaller suppliers.

9.46am BST

Data firm Allies has created an interactive map, showing exactly where Sainsburyâ€™s and Asdaâ€™s stores are today.

It also shows Argos outlets (Sainsburyâ€™s acquired Argos in 2016), so it gives a good idea of where there might be competition issues.

Updated at 9.46am BST

9.23am BST

Sainsbury's-Asda: The key charts

Here are the vital statistics about todayâ€™s merger - showing how a combined Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda will leap-frog Tesco:

9.11am BST

Sainsburyâ€™s chief executive, Mike Coupe, has been speaking to journalists.

He says heâ€™s 100% confident that stores wonâ€™t need to close following the merger with Asda.

However, the regulators may insist that some stores are sold off. There are scores of places where Sainsbury and Asda stores are close by, giving the combined company a dominant position.

8.58am BST

Union: We won't accept job cuts

Britainâ€™s unions are demanding guarantees for workers at Asda.

Tim Roache, general secretary of the GMB, fears that staff at the supermarket will pay the price as Sainsbury pursues the Â£500m of cost savings promised this morning:

â€œHundreds of thousands of workers stand to be affected, and all know such announcements tend to be followed by management speak like â€˜rationalisationâ€™ in the name of â€˜efficiencyâ€™. What that usually means is job losses or cuts to pay, terms and conditions which would be wholly unacceptable. Not least because ASDA workers have already voluntarily agreed to change their contracts to be more flexible in order to play their part and help their employer be more profitable.â€�

â€œIt is quite right to be asking now in whose interests this proposed merger is being tabled. Is it workers and customers or the shareholders and speculators not happy with the hundreds of millions they already make in a year?â€�

Roache is also unhappy that the deal leaked over the weekend, leaving staff worried about their future:

â€œImagine turning up to your Saturday afternoon shifts only to learn this news, with no word from your employer at all - just speculation in the media. Our members are concerned for their futures and angry theyâ€™ve been kept in the dark.â€�

â€œASDA is hugely profitable supermarket, posting hundreds of millions in profit and backed by hundreds of billions from their US parent company, Walmart. Asdaâ€™s success has been built on the back of its workers and it is they who now need and deserve answers and reassurances about their futures - thatâ€™s the least they deserve, and the very least their union will be demanding.â€�

Sainsburyâ€™s has spelled out the terms of its planned merger with rival Asda and promised that shoppers would get a 10% cut in the price of popular foods as a result.

It said it would pay Walmart, the US owner of Leeds-based Asda, nearly Â£3bn in cash and give it a 42% stake in the combined business to complete the deal.

The companies said both brand names would be retained and there were no plans for store closures as a result of creating the group comprising 2,800 stores with sales of Â£51bn, overtaking Tesco to become the UKâ€™s largest retailer, with a workforce of 330,000 people.

However, the Sainsburyâ€™s chief executive, Mike Coupe, said some stores could be sold off to other grocers if required by competition regulators.

Rebecca Long-Bailey, the shadow business secretary, warned of the impact of the deal on suppliers and the GMB general secretary, Tim Roache, said the deal could hit jobs.

John Colley, a professor at Warwick Business School, said: â€œUltimately there has to be job losses and the suppliers will have to pay through lower prices â€¦ customers will see reduced choice.â€�

However, responding to an urgent question about the deal in parliament, the business minister, Andrew Griffiths, appeared to support the merger, saying the two grocers were trying â€œto get ahead of the curveâ€� in a competitive market.

Sainsburyâ€™s shares soared 20% as the stock market welcomed the details of the deal on Monday morning and closed up 15% at 320p, their highest level since 2014.

The proposed merger of the UKâ€™s second and third largest retailers is expected to trigger a major competition inquiry. Analysts predicted that if the deal was approved, it would result in at least 75 store disposals to ensure competition did not suffer. It would be the biggest shake-up in the market since Morrison bought Safeway in 2003, when dozens of stores changed hands.

Sainsburyâ€™s said the merger would not be completed until the second half of 2019 as regulators will have to calculate the potential overlaps between the two groupsâ€™ stores and the impact on local competition.

Related: Sainsbury's and Asda promise price cuts after agreeing deal to create UK's biggest supermarket chain - business live

Coupe, who plans to lead the merged business, said the deal was a â€œtransformational opportunity to create a new force in UK retail, which will be more competitive and give customers more of what they want now and in the futureâ€�. He insisted the merger would be â€œa great deal for everyoneâ€�, with benefits for customers, staff, suppliers and shareholders.

Coupe said the retail landscape had changed dramatically since the Morrisons/Safeway deal, with the rise of discounters Aldi and Lidl and online specialists led by Amazon.

â€œItâ€™s never been more competitive and customers have more choices than ever, not just in the grocery sector but in other retail sectors. You can see the consequences of that playing out every day,â€� Coupe said.

The CMA confirmed the deal would be subject to investigation and Sainsburyâ€™s said it had asked the watchdog to skip straight to a detailed â€œphase twoâ€� stage.

Coupe said regulators would be mainly concerned by the impact on consumers who, he said, would benefit from lower prices and more choice in deciding how they shopped as a result of investment in technology.

He said the merger would deliver at least Â£500m in cost savings and other benefits, largely as a result of improved efficiency and better deals with suppliers.

John Hannett, the general secretary of the Usdaw union, said: â€œBoth companies operate significant nationwide distribution networks employing thousands of staff. We will be seeking urgent clarification on the future for those workers.â€�

Coupe admitted that some head office functions were likely to be combined over time but insisted new jobs would also be created.

Asda will continue to be run from Leeds with its own chief executive, likely to be the current boss, Roger Burnley, who only recently joined Asda from Sainsburyâ€™s.

Coupe insisted that the Sainsburyâ€™s brand, which has prided itself on better welfare and food quality standards, would not be damaged by the association with Walmart, an international retail giant best known for its low prices.

The deal enables Walmart, which bought Asda nearly 20 years ago, to take a step back from the UK market, where it is struggling to compete with Aldi and Lidl as well as Tesco, which controls almost a third of the grocery market.

Judith McKenna, the chief executive of Walmart International, said: â€œWe believe this combination will create a dynamic new retail player better positioned for even more success in a fast-changing and competitive UK market.â€�

She said Walmart was interested in expanding the Sainsburyâ€™s-owned Argos chain internationally and could help the combined business by introducing new technology and better deals on non-food goods.

The biggest shareholder in Sainsburyâ€™s , the Qatar Investment Authority, which holds a 22% stake, announced its intention to support the merger.

Sainsburyâ€™s shares rose 15% on the idea of combining with Asda. One can see why. The chief executive, Mike Coupe â€“ who was on Monday captured on camera by ITV singing â€œWeâ€™re in the moneyâ€� â€“ is promising a Â£500m-a-year boost to profits. Tesco would be knocked off its top perch. And Walmart, after a bruising few years in the UK, is selling Asda on loserâ€™s terms â€“ the Americans have even agreed to tow away Asdaâ€™s pension fund. Fine â€“ but donâ€™t sing too soon. This deal needs regulatory approval and then has to be made to work. There are reasons to be sceptical.

First, Coupeâ€™s view of how the Competition and Markets Authority will view his â€œhistoricâ€� reshaping of the UK grocery market sounded optimistic. He said the CMA applies â€œa higher level of sophisticationâ€� these days than the â€œblunt fascia testâ€� that prevailed in 2003 when Tesco, Asda and Sainsburyâ€™s were barred from buying Safeway. Does it really?

Related: Sainsbury's vows to slash prices after Asda merger

It is true the CMA is fond of measuring competition at a local level and that discounters Aldi and Lidl are now forces in the land. But Sainsburyâ€™s/Asda plus Tesco would control more than half the UK grocery market, which is close to being a working definition of a duopoly. However many local studies are produced, that concentration of national power is hard to ignore.

Coupe claimed an expanded Sainsburyâ€™s would have only 26% of the market, not the 31% estimated by independent agencies, but he included M&S and Boots in his reckoning, which showed how hard he was straining to position this deal within traditional parameters. Unless one is living off a diet of sandwiches and Lucozade, Boots is not a grocer.

This deal is a bet on a CMA that is being asked to sanction a huge structural change in a market where competition is working well. Sainsburyâ€™s and Walmart will inevitably be told to sell some stores, and would probably be relieved if the figure is only 70 or so. At double that, though, some of the commercial benefits will evaporate.

A second problem is Coupeâ€™s assertion that consumers will benefit via 10% price cuts on â€œmany of the products customers buy regularlyâ€�. How many products? How long will the price cuts last? And what about products that are bought less often? He didnâ€™t say. While shareholders are promised Â£500m-a-year of quick savings, shoppers are being asked to take a lot on trust, as the CMA will surely also note.

Nor did Coupe say that Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda will sell identical products at identical prices after equalising buying terms. In fact, the proposed â€œtwo-brandâ€� strategy suggests the opposite approach. How will that work? If a common buying team is buying Coca-Cola or Heinz ketchup at a fixed price, surely Sainsburyâ€™s customers in the new world would expect to pay the same as Asda shoppers. Fluffy boardroom talk about the different â€œbrand positioningâ€� may cut little ice.

Related: Experts have their say on the Sainsbury's and Asda merger

One can admire Coupeâ€™s imagination and opportunism. He has correctly identified Walmartâ€™s weariness with the UK and, rather than sit around waiting for Amazon to make its inevitable attack on the UK supermarket sector, he is trying to make preparations. Thatâ€™s what heâ€™s paid to do. More UK taxes, presumably from Asda not posting dividends across the Atlantic, will play well with UK politicians. His broadside against â€œmultinationalâ€� suppliers with fatter profit margins than supermarkets â€“ who are thus able to trim their prices â€“ also hit the mark.

Coupe claimed an expanded Sainsburyâ€™s would have only 26% of the market, not the 31% estimated by independent agencies, but he included M&S and Boots in his reckoning, which showed how hard he was straining to position this deal within traditional parameters. Unless one is living off a diet of sandwiches and Lucozade, Boots is not a grocer. This deal is a bet on a CMA that is being asked to sanction a huge structural change in a market where competition is working well. Sainsburyâ€™s and Walmart will inevitably be told to sell some stores, and would probably be relieved if the figure is only 70 or so. At double that, though, some of the commercial benefits will evaporate. A second problem is Coupeâ€™s assertion that consumers will benefit via 10% price cuts on â€œmany of the products customers buy regularlyâ€�. How many products? How long will the price cuts last? And what about products that are bought less often? He didnâ€™t say. While shareholders are promised Â£500m-a-year of quick savings, shoppers are being asked to take a lot on trust, as the CMA will surely also note. Nor did Coupe say that Sainsburyâ€™s and Asda will sell identical products at identical prices after equalising buying terms. In fact, the proposed â€œtwo-brandâ€� strategy suggests the opposite approach. How will that work? If a common buying team is buying Coca-Cola or Heinz ketchup at a fixed price, surely Sainsburyâ€™s customers in the new world would expect to pay the same as Asda shoppers. Fluffy boardroom talk about the different â€œbrand positioningâ€� may cut little ice. One can admire Coupeâ€™s imagination and opportunism. He has correctly identified Walmartâ€™s weariness with the UK and, rather than sit around waiting for Amazon to make its inevitable attack on the UK supermarket sector, he is trying to make preparations. Thatâ€™s what heâ€™s paid to do. More UK taxes, presumably from Asda not posting dividends across the Atlantic, will play well with UK politicians. His broadside against â€œmultinationalâ€� suppliers with fatter profit margins than supermarkets â€“ who are thus able to trim their prices â€“ also hit the mark. But his Asda deal faces 12-18 months of intense regulatory scrutiny. Itâ€™s not yet over the line, and the gamble will rebound on Sainsburyâ€™s if the CMA plays rough.
